milestone.title: v1.15.0
milestone.description:
This release fixes a vulnerability where Syncthing and the relay server can crash due to malformed relay protocol messages (CVE-2021-21404); see https://github.com/syncthing/syncthing/security/advisories/GHSA-x462-89pf-6r5h.

This release updates the CLI to use subcommands and adds the subcommands `cli` (previously standalone `stcli` utility) and `decrypt` (for offline verifying and decrypting encrypted folders).

With this release we invite everyone to test the "untrusted (encrypted) devices" feature. You should not use it yet on important production data. Thus UI controls are hidden behind a feature flag. For more information, visit: 
https://forum.syncthing.net/t/testing-untrusted-encrypted-devices/16470

body:
Was discovered in https://forum.syncthing.net/t/problem-adding-second-trusted-device-connected-to-untrusted-device/16538

> 
> Prerequisites
> 
>     Devices A+B: Discovery and nat traversal deactivated, Relaying on (Windows x32)
>     Device U: Discovery, nat traversal and relaying deactivated (Ubuntu 20.04 64bit)
>     All Devices on v1.15.0-rc.5, Windows machines using SyncTrayzor
>     Devices A and B are connected to U. Status: Connected (unused)
> 
> Steps to reproduce
> 
>     Add new Folder to Device A and share it with encryption password
>     Receive Folder on U and add it.
> 
> => U will now show “Up to date” but will not receive any data. A will show “Syncing” for the device and “up to date” for the folder while not sending any data.
> 
>     Pause the new Folder on A and resume it
> 
> => A and U will now sync but U will now have the unencrypted data at the chosen path.

A connection handles multiple folders, every single can be encrypted or not. Which folders are or not encrypted is set when the connection is created. At the time the code was written that was ok, as we dropped a connections when any folder changed. Now we don't anymore, thus adding an encrypted folder doesn't make that connection encrypted until the connection is dropped (restart, device pause, ...).

Should this go into the changelog? It's definitely a "note-worthy" bug, but the untrusted feature is still in testing/preview. Not sure.

The point about having to pause and resume the folder to make anything happen is unrelated (did repro but don't yet know why it happens).
